Topic.Title: When does BAC hit 20?

Message.Msg: Have to wait and see how certain things turn out, such as the $8.5 billion settlement, AIG's $10 billion lawsuit, and the many other lawsuits still pending against the bank. In addition, we need to see what the impact will be of the FDIC's proposed changes in capital leverage ratios. More money tied up in capital means fewer loans which means less earnings.

Message.Msg: one man can make a difference in economic growrth, one plane being flown under human instead of automated control created jobs not just for clean up crew but also for emergency heroes who even may have run over one victim creating even more jobs for "Quincy" types. It is also important to remember that no mortgage player ever killed anyone due to human error execpt if you caount secondary problems from displacing people from homes due to bursting ego bubbles. Luckily everyone from the UAW to the AMA has been against automation and now you can see why, how many jobs and heroes have machines displaced? How much longer have people who know how to read and write communicated non-heroic messages and solved recurring problems that made heroes and made life worth living and luzing? ROFLMFO. It is easy to look at the burned out airplane and think about disrupted travel plans and human injuries, but remember all the heroes and economic growth it created and remember how much safer it is to trade tampons that try to lurn how to fly. If people were meant to wortk with dangerours equipment, financials would have no reason to exist and be cosntantly bailedout for making people feel good. And what about doctors? They end up killing people too. Did mozillo ever kill anyone due to his own negligence? If you are holding out for a hero, submit an abstract to the Al Bundy Kyle Dube economics conference. ROFLMFO. welcome to the human network. You will urn all of this at the la bundy kyle dube economic and social development workshop if you pay the admission fee and get microhipped to gain access to all the events. ROFLMFO. Topic.Title: come, follow me I will make you fishers of compliements ROFLMFO.

Message.Msg: Yelling incoherently at a moral monday crowd isn't likely to scatter them; they'll just assume I'm speaking in tongues and hail me as the Second Coming. And excuse me, but yelling coherently into a 100 mph slipstream is all but impossible and a worthless exercise anyway given the racket that radial makes. Exercising the Beech's new crop-dusting tanks and sprayers, on the other hand.......priceless. If I had to bet on root cause for the SFO mishap I'd put my money on cockpit management and/or automated flight control systems. Ever watch the film of that Airbus full of journalists that crashed on a low-level flyby at the Paris Air Show some years back? Pilot had completed his pass and pushed the throttles forward to climb; flight control system rejected his command, "sorry, busy landing...." More bad news this AM; one of the satellite dishes I clipped was mounted on the roof of a Featherlite Vantaire Platinum Plus Motor Coach registered to one Steven Alan Weinberg. I don't know who the old coot is, but he seems to have some muscle in these parts. Those unsmoked vintage meerschaums have been declared 'drug paraphernalia' and my bail has been raised from $50K to $1M. I'm too smart to need a lawyer, though....I'll either paper the issue over by establishing The American Heritage Foundation For Virgin Turkish Pipes, or ask for immunity in exchange for information on the whereabouts of 1000s of other pieces of 'drug paraphernalia'. ROTFLMAO sorry, IAPCPR convention goers, but I had to throw you under the RV...

Message.Title: Spending during Reagan's two terms (FY 1981–88) averaged 22.4% GDP, well above the 20.6%
Message.Msg: Spending during Reagan's two terms (FY 1981–88) averaged 22.4% GDP, well above the 20.6% GDP average from 1971 to 2009. In addition, the public debt rose from 26% GDP in 1980 to 41% GDP by 1988. In dollar terms, the public debt rose from $712 billion in 1980 to $2,052 billion in 1988,

Topic.Title: BAC ALREADY HAS DOUBLE THE FED'S NEW 5% LEVERAGE RULE

Message.Msg: Actually, I don't think you are correct. I haven't been able to sort it out yet, but you need to remember that the capital ratios that have been discussed most are the Tier 1 Equity Capital, and that is risk weighted, which is why it is higher. The new leverage ratio proposed by the FDIC is basically a flat ratio without risk weightings, meaning everything is treated the same.

Topic.Title: Regulators propose 6 pct leverage ratio. Non issue for BAC, its almost there.

Message.Msg: I think you'll find, if you look at their past quarterly financial reports and presentations, that BAC always states their capital levels and ratios at the BAC or corporate level. Then, further down in the documents, they will show how that total capital is allocated among the various divisions. They do not report the "bank" and "Merrill" capital separately.

Topic.Title: BAC ALREADY HAS DOUBLE THE FED'S NEW 5% LEVERAGE RULE

Message.Msg: As for whatever "report" you just read, unless it was from Sandler it was written by either a sellsider who is incomptent or, more lilely, one of the pseudo journalists posing as an analyst with his head up his hiney. See, I actually know what i am talking about. LOL BAC's earning power is only now going to become visible as the margin expands and the strucural de-risking/reduced provisioning sinks in on the ridiculously ill-informed and sophomoric pm running managed money out there. BAC's CURRENT capital and earning power leaves them better than all set, and you can take a few months to figure it out or just ignore my comments -- see if I care. The FDIC proposal focuses on tangible common to risk-weighted assets... the Fed Reserve rule passed today is all about tangible common to tangible assets as defined. Stay tuned but BAC will continue to repurchase shares and the expensive preferreds.

Topic.Title: BAC ALREADY HAS DOUBLE THE FED'S NEW 5% LEVERAGE RULE

Message.Msg: Sorry, but I think you are the one who has it wrong: "The eight biggest U.S. banks will need to hold twice as much equity capital as required globally under a new plan proposed by regulators on Tuesday intended to protect taxpayers from any future costly bailouts. The rule would impose a so-called leverage ratio, a hard cap on how much banks can borrow to fund their business, requiring them to hold equity capital equal to 6 percent of total assets."

Topic.Title: BAC ALREADY HAS DOUBLE THE FED'S NEW 5% LEVERAGE RULE

Message.Msg: "The 6 percent ratio covers the banking units insured by the FDIC, one of the three regulators that proposed the rule. The regulators also proposed a leverage ratio of 5 percent for holding companies that own the insured banks and also include far more risky investment banking activities."

Topic.Title: BAC ALREADY HAS DOUBLE THE FED'S NEW 5% LEVERAGE RULE

Message.Msg: "Before the FDIC proposal came out, analysts, on average, estimated leverage ratios at 4.6 percent for Morgan Stanley; 5.1 percent for Citigroup; 5.3 percent for JPMorgan Chase; 5.7 percent for Goldman and Bank of America Corp; and 7.5 percent for Wells Fargo."

Message.Title: Banks will need to raise more capital up to 6%....why not 10%%%
Message.Msg: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The eight biggest U.S. banks will need to hold twice as much equity capital as required globally under a new rule launched by U.S. regulators on Tuesday, intended to protect taxpayers from any future costly bailouts. The rule, launched by the country's three main banking regulators, would impose a so-called leverage ratio, a hard cap on how much banks can borrow to fund their business, requiring them to hold equity capital equal to 6 percent of total assets. The global capital accord known as Basel III, named after the Swiss city that is home to overseer Bank of International Settlements, sets a leverage ratio of 3 percent, which critics say is unambitious. "A three percent minimum supplementary leverage ratio would not have appreciably mitigated the growth in leverage ... in the years preceding the recent crisis," Martin Gruenberg, who heads the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp, said at a public meeting on Tuesday. The banks would have until January 2018 to meet the new requirements. FDIC staffers said it should not be difficult for the megabanks to hit the targets, but bank groups warned that the heightened levels could harm the economic recovery.

Topic.Title: #$%$ Bove was on CNBC this morning

Message.Msg: Banks are going to have a "pretty tough" time logging a 15th-straight quarter of higher year-over-year earnings, banking analyst #$%$ Bove told CNBC on Tuesday. The major banks, including JPMorgan and Wells Fargo, begin to report second quarter profits on Friday. Armchair Analyst Poll: Will JPMorgan Q2 earnings Friday meet, beat, or miss Wall Street expectations of $1.43 a share? Vote Now! Meet Beat Miss Vote to see results "This should be a sloppy quarter," Bove said in a "Squawk Box" interview. "The reason is pretty simple: Banks do pretty much what the economy does." (Vote Now on Facebook in the "Squawk Box" Armchair Analyst Poll) The final revision for first quarter economic growth was a more tepid 1.8 percent annual rate than previously estimated. And when the government releases its first look at second quarter growth later this month, the number won't be good, Bove said. "We did not have a great second quarter from an economic standpoint," he said. "So we're not going to have a great second quarter in terms of bank earnings." He ticked off the reasons: "Loan volume in the two big areas, commercial industrial and residential mortgage, have slowed down dramatically. Price competition has picked up to push margins lower." "You got this issue with long-term rates going up creating issues about capital," he added. "You've got the fact that trading did pick up pretty good for a couple months in the quarter, but wasn't great the whole quarter."

Message.Msg: Surprisingly, yay-who's crack [smoking] security services did allow your missive fly, and yes, kinda hard to find any harbingers of a booming global economy in the BDI charts. However, you don't seem to understand the mindset of the congregation you're preaching to. Surely you don't expect a herd that follows leaders shouting "Go BAC! $20 dollars by 4PM on Tuesday!" and "BAC is pure evil.....50 cents by year's end!" to pay any attention to a chart that has historically been one of the best leading indicators of FUTURE economic activity, do you? ROTFLMAO don't you understand that BAC is totally unique among corporations, absolutely immune to 'normal' market forces, and moves in perfect synchronicity with the ebb and flow of battle in the eternal war between good and evil, Satan and Jesus, or on occasion Ben and the whims of judges and politicians? Topic.Title: the fastest way to get censored on here...

Message.Msg: It's so painful to be right all the time, but I'd still reserve a little space for the crash investigators to operate before resting my case. Diagnostics are fine, sensors can be iffy, software is full of bugs or less-than-robust code, but at the end of the day (or flight) it's usually the man-machine interface that breaks down. Nobody else was reporting wind shear problems; weather and visibility were fine or better, and I almost fell over when some CNN bimbette solemnly declared that any over-water approach is dangerous when in fact they are among the safest and easiest of approaches. Try dropping a high-lift bird like the Staggerwing between tall buildings, through billowing thermals, and then side-slip it over a row of palm trees into a parking lot full of RVs with a casino lobby for an over-run, and driving a tour bus through an over-water approach starts to look like something Helen Keller could manage without a copilot or navigator. By way of comparison again, taking off out of Circus-Circus will make landing there look like a cakewalk into town. It'll be the real acid test for the 750 horse engine mod and Sensenich variable pitch prop. Pass or fail, I can promise a noisy spectacle....ROTFLMAO if I can ever get my rump out of stir. Has viewer been delayed in traffic or having trouble finding good sushi and fresh Ibogaine? I can't believe she hasn't visited me yet....

Message.Title: Keep It Slow & Steady
Message.Msg: Very happy with the slow ascent into the low teens. I watched this in March 2009 and was scared to buy (also loved Ford at $2). Finally bought at 7.50 and sold at 8.50 (got nervous cause my planner told me to sell...he actually quoted a negative assessment from Morningstar....ha-ha.). Finally after doing a lot of my own reading I bought back in at 11.24..I am looking at selling once it hits 31...it will be a rocky ride with ups and downs, but look at the 5 year chart...I feel it will get back. This is the 2nd largest bank in the country, come on...they are running it well these days...have patience folks...it will pay off in the future. BTW, I bought 15,000 shares at that price. My financial planner said I was nuts to take such a risk, but again, I liked what I researched. Make your own informed decisions...
